paragraphs: AAU provides an exceptional educational experience to all students that prepares them for successful completion, employability and job creation.
AAU is a leader in developing transdisciplinary solutions to social, economic, political, and environmental challenges.
As a dynamic resource with nationally prestigious academic programs and research projects, AAU partners with industry offering numerous solutions to real and pressing problems.
Tikur Anbessa Specialized Hospital is the largest referral hospital in Ethiopia serving over a million patients from across the country annually.
Our university has produced numerous notable alumni
The best university in East Africa
More than 208k+ Graduates
12,293 Scholarly Outputs Since 2014
Events and Activities
Our students engage in events, activities, and clubs year-round across all campuses. From holiday celebrations to club involvement and voluntary work, we offer plenty of opportunities to socialize.
Annual Sports Festival
Experience the spirit of competition and community at AAU's Annual Sports Festival, celebrating excellence in student athletics and intercollegiate unity.
The Addis Ababa University Libraries support academic growth with a vast collection of resources, study spaces, and research services for students and faculty.
We provide a variety of housing and dining options based on eligibility criteria set by AAU's regulations and policies
IES, Sidist Kilo Campus
Ethiopia's first university museum dating back to the early 1950s, rich with huge collections of artifacts, traditional tools and equipment, historical heritages, and many more.
The National Herbarium is rich with large collections of mummified plants and wild animals, including those that are endemic to Ethiopia.
Sefere Selam Campus is a hub of research and medical training centers offering qualifications in several domains.
If you are interested in becoming a partner, please feel free to contact us.

paragraphs: AAU provides a broad range of services that include  clinical, entrepreneurial support, publishing, book sales, ICT, sports, museum, art and culture services.

A wide variety of services and tools are available across AAU’s campuses to assist students, faculty and staff with teaching, learning, catering, medical, digital, business and a broad range of other services.

The Addis Ababa University Book Center, founded in 1984 G.C., has played a crucial role in supporting academic growth and providing essential resources to the university community. Over the years, it has grown into a vital hub for educational publications, stationery, and other services.

title: AAU | Addis Ababa University
paragraphs: Student life at Addis Ababa University is characterized by a commitment to academic excellence, cultural exchange, social activities, active student participation and personal development opportunities. Students often cherish their experiences at AAU, forming lasting friendships and gaining valuable skills that contribute to their personal and preparing them for their future careers and lives.

Addis Ababa University's commitment to sports and recreation contributes to a holistic educational experience, allowing students to develop physically, socially, and psychologically while enjoying their time at the university. The sports and recreation initiatives at Addis Ababa University play a vital role in creating a vibrant campus life, promoting physical fitness, and encouraging teamwork and collaboration among students. Once a year, in every campus and among campuses of the University, intramural and intercampus sports competitions will be organized for regular undergraduate students.
The Student Finance Services supportively engaged in facilitating cost-sharing agreements, processing dormitory and meal payments, and maintaining transparent and accurate financial records.

title: AAU | Addis Ababa University
paragraphs: AAU has a legacy of producing remarkable alumni who excel in leadership, science, arts, and advocacy. These distinguished graduates reflect AAU's commitment to excellence and societal impact. Their achievements continue to inspire and shape the future of Ethiopia, Africa, and the world. Some of the most notable alumni include:

Rupiah Bwezani Banda was a Zambian politician who served as the fourth president of Zambia from 2008 to 2011, taking over from Levy Mwanawasa. Banda was an active participant in politics from early in the presidency of Kenneth Kaunda, during which time he held several diplomatic posts.
Nationality: Ethiopian

Hailemariam Desalegn Boshe is an Ethiopian politician who served as prime minister of Ethiopia from 2012 to 2018. He also previously served as deputy prime minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs under Prime Minister Meles Zenawi from 2010 to 2012. After Meles' death in August 2012, Hailemariam succeeded him as prime minister, initially in an acting capacity. He was then elected as the chair of the EPRDF, the ruling party, on 15 September 2012. Hailemariam also served as the chairperson of the African Union from 2013 to 2014.
Nationality: Ethiopian

Yohannes Haile-Selassie Ambaye is an Ethiopian paleoanthropologist. An authority on pre-Homo sapiens hominids, he particularly focuses his attention on the East African Rift and Middle Awash valleys. He was curator of Physical Anthropology at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History from 2002 until 2021, and now is serving as the director of the Arizona State University Institute of Human Origins. Since founding the institute in 1981, he has been the third director after Donald Johanson and William Kimbel.
Nationality: Ethiopian

Meaza Ashenafi is an Ethiopian lawyer. In November 2018, she was appointed by the Federal Parliamentary Assembly as President of the Federal Supreme Court of Ethiopia until her resignation on 17 January 2023.
Nationality: Ethiopian
Aklilu Lemma was an Ethiopian pathologist. In 1989, he was awarded the Right Livelihood Award 'for discovering and campaigning relentlessly for an affordable preventative against bilharzia.

Hailemariam also served as the chairperson of the African Union from 2013 to 2014.Read MoreYohannes Haile-SelassieNationality: EthiopianYohannes Haile-Selassie Ambaye is an Ethiopian paleoanthropologist. An authority on pre-Homo sapiens hominids, he particularly focuses his attention on the East African Rift and Middle Awash valleys. He was curator of Physical Anthropology at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History from 2002 until 2021, and now is serving as the director of the Arizona State University Institute of Human Origins. Since founding the institute in 1981, he has been the third director after Donald Johanson and William Kimbel.Read MoreMeaza AshenafiNationality: EthiopianMeaza Ashenafi is an Ethiopian lawyer. In November 2018, she was appointed by the Federal Parliamentary Assembly as President of the Federal Supreme Court of Ethiopia until her resignation on 17 January 2023.Read MoreAklilu LemmaNationality: EthiopianAklilu Lemma was an Ethiopian pathologist. In 1989, he was awarded the Right Livelihood Award 'for discovering and campaigning relentlessly for an affordable preventative against bilharzia.Read MoreAnnouncementsView allSubscribe to our Newsletter.Subscribe

title: AAU | Addis Ababa University
paragraphs: Community Radio-the Voice of AAU

AAU has been Ethiopia's best university and one of Africa's most respected institutions of higher learning. The University's community radio has been a part of the university's success as a prestigious public higher education.

While chiefly pandering to the university community, the radio station carries a variety of programming, including a news bulletin, sports, and music for the broader AA city community. It is also devoted to educational enrichment, community conversation, community engagement, and cultural development. The station promotes peaceful co-existence and intercultural tolerance through diverse formats including drama series, and inculcates a sense of good citizenship in the student community The radio station is located on the FBE campus and broadcasts daily for seven and a half hours.

title: AAU | Addis Ababa University

headings.text: The Institute of Ethiopian Studies Ethnographic Museum

paragraphs: The Ethnographic Museum of the Institute of Ethiopian Studies which is located at the main campus of Addis Ababa University (AAU) is the first university museum in Ethiopia. Since 1963 it has been serving the public at large in awareness creation of the about Ethiopia's diverge population of cultural resources. It is cultural institution dedicated to the preservation, reserve and presentation of Ethiopia's rich cultural heritage. The museum was established with the intention of conserving the nation's heritage, conducting pertinent research, and supporting educational endeavors of the People of Ethiopia Its collection exceeds 16,000 items, including religious and secular manuscripts, ceremonial items, icons, paintings, basketry, poetry, hand crafts, traditional weapons and musical instruments textiles, as well as, crosses, and philatelies. Some artifacts even date back to the early Aksumite period. The Ethnographic Museum is also a place where visitors enjoy as well as researchers conduct their research actively in projects related to heritage and museum studies. It is open to visitors from Monday to Sunday, excluding public holidays. Guides are available at all Times to provide information and insights about the collections. Entrance fees are charged at different rates for adults and students.

title: AAU | Addis Ababa University
paragraphs: The College of Health Sciences (CHS) is a professional health sciences college, established in 2009/10 by the reorganization of previously separate institutions of health under one umbrella. The CHS is comprised of four schools and one teaching hospital. The four schools are the School of Medicine (SoM), the School of Pharmacy (SoP), the School of Public Health (SPH) and the School of Allied Health Sciences (SAHS). The SAHS offers professional training in nursing, midwifery and medical laboratory technology. The rationale behind the establishment of the CHS is to encourage cross-breeding across various disciplinary paradigms;

standardize curricula across disciplines; set standards and quality checks for the teaching-learning process; maximize human resources utilization through joint planning in teaching common courses and in conducting research; create opportunities in collaborative research and publication; maximize shared use of facilities for effectiveness and efficiency in teaching-learning, research and services, and create opportunities to address the health needs of the community in an integrated manner as a health team. All Schools of the CHS offer professional degrees at both undergraduate and postgraduate levels except for the School of Public Health which offers only postgraduate degrees at MSc and PhD levels.

However, the SPH is heavily engaged in offering public health courses to undergraduate students of the other Schools in the CHS. The CHS currently has over 5000 students, and employs over 600 full-time faculty members, The College currently offers eight undergraduate and over 70 postgraduate programs. The Tikur Abessa Specialized Hospital (TASH) is the teaching hospital of the College. TASH is the largest specialized hospital in Ethiopia, with over 700 beds, and serves as a training center for undergraduate and postgraduate medical students, dentists, nurses, midwives, pharmacists, medical laboratory technologists, radiology technologists, and others who shoulder the health problems of the community and the country at large.

In line with the mission and vision of AAU, the CHS exercises unique roles in training highly skilled health professionals at MSc, PhD, specialty and subspecialty levels. This allows it to contribute to the expansion of quality health care, education and research in the country. The CHS is the only institution where some specialized tertiary health care is rendered.
Moreover, under the new structure of AAU, the CHS is expected to enjoy a high level of academic and administrative autonomy.

title: AAU | Addis Ababa University
paragraphs: The Ashenafi Kebede Performing Arts Center (AKPAC) is a newly established cultural and performance venue founded by Addis Ababa University, one of Africa’s oldest and most influential academic institutions. Located within the historic Yared School of Music, AKPAC stands as a renewed commitment to nurturing the arts, preserving cultural heritage, and expanding creative expression in Ethiopia.

The center is named in honor of Dr. Ashenafi Kebede a pioneering Ethiopian composer, conductor, and ethnomusicologist whose scholarship and artistry helped illuminate and safeguard Ethiopia’s musical traditions. His legacy guides our dedication to artistic integrity, cultural continuity, and educational excellence.

AKPAC serves as a creative home for musicians, actors, dancers, filmmakers, scholars, and cultural professionals. It hosts a wide range of programming, including concerts, theatre productions, film screenings, workshops, exhibitions, festivals, and community gatherings. It is a place where talent is cultivated, dialogue is encouraged, and culture is celebrated in all its diversity.

To advance and promote the performing arts in Ethiopia by providing a professional, inclusive, and inspiring environment for artistic creation, cultural education, and meaningful audience experiences.
To become a leading performing arts hub in Ethiopia and across Africa a center that sparks creativity, nurtures artistic growth, and strengthens the bond between culture, education, and community.
Host Your Event at AKPAC

Whether you are planning a concert, cultural celebration, theatrical performance, film screening, workshop, academic talk, or official gathering AKPAC offers a professional, well-equipped, and welcoming venue for your event.
Our facilities include:
· A 621-seat performance hall
· Fully equipped stage and lighting
· High-quality sound system and grand piano
· Spacious lobby and reception area
· Stand-by generator for uninterrupted events
· Secure parking and on-site security
· Convenient central location in Addis Ababa
Our team is dedicated to delivering smooth coordination and a memorable experience for performers, presenters, and guests.

paragraphs: The Addis Ababa University Startups Center is a dynamic hub for innovation and entrepreneurship, dedicated to empowering students, researchers, and early-stage entrepreneurs as they develop transformative ideas into scalable businesses. In addition to its main facilities, the center includes specialized innovation branches across other AAU campuses, such as the AAiT Innovation Center, the Science Innovation Center, and the Black Lion Hospital Health Innovation Center. These centers provide tailored resources, mentorship, and networking, opportunities to support development across diverse fields-from: technology and engineering to health sciences- driving Ethiopia's economic growth and addressing real world challenges through sustainable Innovation.

paragraphs: AAU is dedicated to the provision of recreational and competitive sports for students, staff and faculty. A broad range of sporting events basketball, handball, tennis, athletics, table tennis, chess involve mass participation through the fan activities. Sports include inter-years, and inter-faculty sports competitions.

Each campus encourages indoor and outdoor activities and clubs help to offer more opportunities to students who are especially passionate about sports. The university also engages students in other extracurricular activities suitable to their desires and preferences including creative arts, volunteering and other areas of passion. Many clubs are formed based on taste and values and help to make university life fun. They also offer opportunities to learn and grow as well as showcase student talent.

AAU Hosts Conference on the Role of the ICJ in Addressing Climate Change in Africa

Addis Ababa University (AAU) hosted a half-day conference at the Sheikh Mohammed Hussein Ali Al-Amoudi Hall under the theme “The Role of the International Court of Justice in Addressing Climate Change in Africa.”

The event brought together students, academics, and legal practitioners to engage in discussions on global legal issues, with particular emphasis on climate-related cases increasingly brought before the International Court of Justice (ICJ).

The conference also explored Africa’s expectations of an independent, effective, and representative ICJ that reflects legal and linguistic diversity while upholding the principle of sovereign equality among states.

Opening the event, Dr. Jeilu Omer, Academic Vice President of Addis Ababa University, underscored the growing importance of international law in addressing global challenges. He noted that international law is not only relevant but also a powerful and essential instrument in responding to climate change.

The guest lecturer, Ambassador François Alabrune, a diplomat and France’s Ambassador to the Netherlands, delivered a lecture on international law, global justice, and climate change. He emphasized that the ICJ’s core role lies in clarifying international law and providing an adaptable legal roadmap for states. While ICJ decisions and advisory opinions are non-binding, he noted that their moral and legal authority remains significant.

Ambassador Alabrune also pointed out that despite the universality of the ICJ, issues related to state sovereignty and equality can limit the Court’s accessibility and impact. He concluded by encouraging African states and non-state actors to play a more active role in addressing climate change through legal and diplomatic means.
The conference was jointly organized by the French Embassy in Ethiopia and the African Union, in collaboration with Addis Ababa University.

The International Court of Justice, the principal judicial organ of the United Nations, was established nearly 80 years ago to adjudicate disputes between states and provide advisory opinions on international legal questions.

He concluded by encouraging African states and non-state actors to play a more active role in addressing climate change through legal and diplomatic means.The conference was jointly organized by the French Embassy in Ethiopia and the African Union, in collaboration with Addis Ababa University.The International Court of Justice, the principal judicial organ of the United Nations, was established nearly 80 years ago to adjudicate disputes between states and provide advisory opinions on international legal questions.Jan 25, 2026Addis Ababa University Ranks First Among East African UniversitiesJan 20, 2026Public Lecture at AAU Highlights Contributions of Prof. Sven Rubenson to Ethiopian HistoryJan 16, 2026Institute of Ethiopian Studies Hosts Symposium on Ethiopian Islamic Manuscript TraditionsJan 11, 2026VIEW MORE NEWSCampusesExplore our CampusesSefere Selam CampusSefere Selam Campus is a hub of research and medical training centers offering qualifications in several domains.Explore this CampusexploreexploreexploreexploreexploreexploreexploreexploreexploreexploreexploreexploreNext slideFEATURED PARTNERSIf you are interested in becoming a partner, please feel free to contact us.Ethio-TelecomeThe Merchant desires to use Ethiotelecom TeleBirr service platform for receiving payment of goods and/or services from customers The Merchant desires to use Ethiotelecom TeleBirr service platform for receiving payment of goods and/or services from customers View allAnnouncementsFirst-Year Students Final online exam ScheduleJan 25, 2026AAU Connect Volume 10 – 75 Years of ExcellenceJan 22, 2026final examination schedule for the course Inclusiveness (for 2nd year Students)Jan 12, 2026GAT Exam Schedule (Monday January 05, 2026 Morning and Afternoon Session)Dec 31, 2025Submission of Updated Grade 12 Examination ResultsDec 25, 2025View allSubscribe to our Newsletter.Subscribe

The sports and recreation initiatives at Addis Ababa University play a vital role in creating a vibrant campus life, promoting physical fitness, and encouraging teamwork and collaboration among students. Once a year, in every campus and among campuses of the University, intramural and intercampus sports competitions will be organized for regular undergraduate students.
The Student Finance Services supportively engaged in facilitating cost-sharing agreements, processing dormitory and meal payments, and maintaining transparent and accurate financial records.

paragraphs: AAU has a legacy of producing remarkable alumni who excel in leadership, science, arts, and advocacy. These distinguished graduates reflect AAU's commitment to excellence and societal impact. Their achievements continue to inspire and shape the future of Ethiopia, Africa, and the world. Some of the most notable alumni include:

Rupiah Bwezani Banda was a Zambian politician who served as the fourth president of Zambia from 2008 to 2011, taking over from Levy Mwanawasa. Banda was an active participant in politics from early in the presidency of Kenneth Kaunda, during which time he held several diplomatic posts.
Nationality: Ethiopian

Hailemariam Desalegn Boshe is an Ethiopian politician who served as prime minister of Ethiopia from 2012 to 2018. He also previously served as deputy prime minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs under Prime Minister Meles Zenawi from 2010 to 2012. After Meles' death in August 2012, Hailemariam succeeded him as prime minister, initially in an acting capacity. He was then elected as the chair of the EPRDF, the ruling party, on 15 September 2012. Hailemariam also served as the chairperson of the African Union from 2013 to 2014.
Nationality: Ethiopian

Yohannes Haile-Selassie Ambaye is an Ethiopian paleoanthropologist. An authority on pre-Homo sapiens hominids, he particularly focuses his attention on the East African Rift and Middle Awash valleys. He was curator of Physical Anthropology at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History from 2002 until 2021, and now is serving as the director of the Arizona State University Institute of Human Origins. Since founding the institute in 1981, he has been the third director after Donald Johanson and William Kimbel.
Nationality: Ethiopian

Meaza Ashenafi is an Ethiopian lawyer. In November 2018, she was appointed by the Federal Parliamentary Assembly as President of the Federal Supreme Court of Ethiopia until her resignation on 17 January 2023.
Nationality: Ethiopian
Aklilu Lemma was an Ethiopian pathologist. In 1989, he was awarded the Right Livelihood Award 'for discovering and campaigning relentlessly for an affordable preventative against bilharzia.

paragraphs: The College of Health Sciences (CHS) is a professional health sciences college, established in 2009/10 by the reorganization of previously separate institutions of health under one umbrella. The CHS is comprised of four schools and one teaching hospital. The four schools are the School of Medicine (SoM), the School of Pharmacy (SoP), the School of Public Health (SPH) and the School of Allied Health Sciences (SAHS). The SAHS offers professional training in nursing, midwifery and medical laboratory technology. The rationale behind the establishment of the CHS is to encourage cross-breeding across various disciplinary paradigms;

standardize curricula across disciplines; set standards and quality checks for the teaching-learning process; maximize human resources utilization through joint planning in teaching common courses and in conducting research; create opportunities in collaborative research and publication; maximize shared use of facilities for effectiveness and efficiency in teaching-learning, research and services, and create opportunities to address the health needs of the community in an integrated manner as a health team. All Schools of the CHS offer professional degrees at both undergraduate and postgraduate levels except for the School of Public Health which offers only postgraduate degrees at MSc and PhD levels.

However, the SPH is heavily engaged in offering public health courses to undergraduate students of the other Schools in the CHS. The CHS currently has over 5000 students, and employs over 600 full-time faculty members, The College currently offers eight undergraduate and over 70 postgraduate programs. The Tikur Abessa Specialized Hospital (TASH) is the teaching hospital of the College. TASH is the largest specialized hospital in Ethiopia, with over 700 beds, and serves as a training center for undergraduate and postgraduate medical students, dentists, nurses, midwives, pharmacists, medical laboratory technologists, radiology technologists, and others who shoulder the health problems of the community and the country at large.

In line with the mission and vision of AAU, the CHS exercises unique roles in training highly skilled health professionals at MSc, PhD, specialty and subspecialty levels. This allows it to contribute to the expansion of quality health care, education and research in the country. The CHS is the only institution where some specialized tertiary health care is rendered.
Moreover, under the new structure of AAU, the CHS is expected to enjoy a high level of academic and administrative autonomy.

paragraphs: The Ashenafi Kebede Performing Arts Center (AKPAC) is a newly established cultural and performance venue founded by Addis Ababa University, one of Africa’s oldest and most influential academic institutions. Located within the historic Yared School of Music, AKPAC stands as a renewed commitment to nurturing the arts, preserving cultural heritage, and expanding creative expression in Ethiopia.

The center is named in honor of Dr. Ashenafi Kebede a pioneering Ethiopian composer, conductor, and ethnomusicologist whose scholarship and artistry helped illuminate and safeguard Ethiopia’s musical traditions. His legacy guides our dedication to artistic integrity, cultural continuity, and educational excellence.

AKPAC serves as a creative home for musicians, actors, dancers, filmmakers, scholars, and cultural professionals. It hosts a wide range of programming, including concerts, theatre productions, film screenings, workshops, exhibitions, festivals, and community gatherings. It is a place where talent is cultivated, dialogue is encouraged, and culture is celebrated in all its diversity.

To advance and promote the performing arts in Ethiopia by providing a professional, inclusive, and inspiring environment for artistic creation, cultural education, and meaningful audience experiences.
To become a leading performing arts hub in Ethiopia and across Africa a center that sparks creativity, nurtures artistic growth, and strengthens the bond between culture, education, and community.
Host Your Event at AKPAC

Whether you are planning a concert, cultural celebration, theatrical performance, film screening, workshop, academic talk, or official gathering AKPAC offers a professional, well-equipped, and welcoming venue for your event.
Our facilities include:
· A 621-seat performance hall
· Fully equipped stage and lighting
· High-quality sound system and grand piano
· Spacious lobby and reception area
· Stand-by generator for uninterrupted events
· Secure parking and on-site security
· Convenient central location in Addis Ababa
Our team is dedicated to delivering smooth coordination and a memorable experience for performers, presenters, and guests.

paragraphs: Community Radio-the Voice of AAU

AAU has been Ethiopia's best university and one of Africa's most respected institutions of higher learning. The University's community radio has been a part of the university's success as a prestigious public higher education.

While chiefly pandering to the university community, the radio station carries a variety of programming, including a news bulletin, sports, and music for the broader AA city community. It is also devoted to educational enrichment, community conversation, community engagement, and cultural development. The station promotes peaceful co-existence and intercultural tolerance through diverse formats including drama series, and inculcates a sense of good citizenship in the student community The radio station is located on the FBE campus and broadcasts daily for seven and a half hours.

paragraphs: The Addis Ababa University Startups Center is a dynamic hub for innovation and entrepreneurship, dedicated to empowering students, researchers, and early-stage entrepreneurs as they develop transformative ideas into scalable businesses. In addition to its main facilities, the center includes specialized innovation branches across other AAU campuses, such as the AAiT Innovation Center, the Science Innovation Center, and the Black Lion Hospital Health Innovation Center. These centers provide tailored resources, mentorship, and networking, opportunities to support development across diverse fields-from: technology and engineering to health sciences- driving Ethiopia's economic growth and addressing real world challenges through sustainable Innovation.

paragraphs: AAU is dedicated to the provision of recreational and competitive sports for students, staff and faculty. A broad range of sporting events basketball, handball, tennis, athletics, table tennis, chess involve mass participation through the fan activities. Sports include inter-years, and inter-faculty sports competitions.

Each campus encourages indoor and outdoor activities and clubs help to offer more opportunities to students who are especially passionate about sports. The university also engages students in other extracurricular activities suitable to their desires and preferences including creative arts, volunteering and other areas of passion. Many clubs are formed based on taste and values and help to make university life fun. They also offer opportunities to learn and grow as well as showcase student talent.

paragraphs: The Ethnographic Museum of the Institute of Ethiopian Studies which is located at the main campus of Addis Ababa University (AAU) is the first university museum in Ethiopia. Since 1963 it has been serving the public at large in awareness creation of the about Ethiopia's diverge population of cultural resources. It is cultural institution dedicated to the preservation, reserve and presentation of Ethiopia's rich cultural heritage. The museum was established with the intention of conserving the nation's heritage, conducting pertinent research, and supporting educational endeavors of the People of Ethiopia Its collection exceeds 16,000 items, including religious and secular manuscripts, ceremonial items, icons, paintings, basketry, poetry, hand crafts, traditional weapons and musical instruments textiles, as well as, crosses, and philatelies. Some artifacts even date back to the early Aksumite period. The Ethnographic Museum is also a place where visitors enjoy as well as researchers conduct their research actively in projects related to heritage and museum studies. It is open to visitors from Monday to Sunday, excluding public holidays. Guides are available at all Times to provide information and insights about the collections. Entrance fees are charged at different rates for adults and students.
